today on hot thai kitchen we are making touch table 
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today

we're making a recipe that's very quick simple and 
super healthy that you can easily whip up for a

weeknight dinner which is always good to have in 
your repertoire of recipes the real reason why I

wanted to do show you this recipe is because it 
uses two of the most two of the very important

herbs in Thai cuisine that for some reason I 
have not used at all in any of my other recipes

and that's just not right so we got to fix that 
so the dish is called pad cha pla and Pad means

to stir-fry cha is the onomatopoeia word for the 
sizzling sound you add something to a hot pan it

goes cha right and pla is fish so it's a very 
straightforward stir-fry a fish with lots and

lots of herbs so here are our ingredients so 
the first herb that is the star of this dish

you cannot have Pacha without it is what we call 
carrot eye or in English is called finger root

and they grow underground their rhizome just 
like ginger and galangal and the girl like mad

in my house in Thailand it's got a very refreshing 
cooling woodsy aroma kind of like Chinese medicine

but in a good way and it's also got a bite to it 
a zing flavor to it it's really hard to describe

so you really got to experience it for yourself if 
you if you haven't used it before fresh ones are

really hard to find so you cannot find fresh look 
for brined ones become it come in a jar like this

and they're actually relatively easy to find in 
a lot of Asian grocery stores sometimes they come

whole but a lot of times they'll come shredded up 
like this which is good because most of the time

this is how we use it we're gonna have to chop it 
up anyway often labelled rhizome in brine which

I know doesn't make any sense but anyway look for 
catch eye sometimes it's called galangal which is

I'm not sure that's an actual word but just look 
for this you can't mistake it if it looks like

that that's what it is okay so that one works 
really well in fish recipes most of the time

we use catch I in fish recipes because it works 
well to soften any fishiness of the fish so the

second ingredient that's very important is what we 
call prick tight on or young peppercorns I don't

have any fresh ones for you today because I don't 
have any but I have a brined one which also works

really well when things are brian do they actually 
hold up pretty well and these are basically what

your black and white peppercorns used to be before 
they were dried and process so it's just a young

green pepper and it's got a very peppery aroma but 
what it does it's a different kind of heat from

it's quite hot but it's a different kind of heat 
from chilies it feels like the temperature of your

mouth is actually rising when when you bite into 
one of these so what I did is just take them off

into little rounds like this just take them off 
the stems so that you get like one or two in every

bite but you're afraid that it's gonna be too hot 
for you leave them on the stems toss the stems in

and then people can sort of pick the seats off 
the stems as they eat it so one last thing I

want to talk about before we get started is the 
fish I'm using halibut today because a nice firm

flesh fish which is good for stir frying you can 
use other types of fish I've used tilapia works

really well leaving the skin on is nice because 
the skin will help hold the fish together and

it won't break so easily other types of seafood 
is very common for this dish shrimp scallops if

you're feeling fancy squid if you like squid works 
really well as well so you can be creative on that

Department and I just got the fish marinated in 
half a tablespoon of fish sauce and it was like

fish sauce on fish it's like super fishy fish 
but no it's gonna be good just put it in just

put the fish sauce on while you're prepping other 
ingredients it doesn't need to sit for you know

two hours or anything like that and I cut it into 
large ish cubes so they don't break too much when

we're going to stir fry them okay so that's all 
I need to talk about as far as ingredients go so

let's get started so the first thing we're gonna 
do is make an herb paste so think of this as like

a simple curry paste okay so I've got our garlic 
in here and also our cilantro roots which I have

chopped up you can also do a bunch of cilantro 
stems if you don't have some Thai chilies as much

as you'd like white peppercorns it's a little bit 
redundant because we have the young peppercorns

already but you know I love white pepper so I'm 
gonna add it so if you that's another thing if

you don't have the young peppercorn just put in 
extra white peppercorns my spur chilies which I

have cut up and if you don't have spiritually 
so what we hope it's cheap I just use any mild

peppers what we want is the chili pepper chili 
pepper flavor without the heat so you can use bell

peppers of you if you really can't find anything 
else or any other chilies that are available in

your local grocer grocery it doesn't even have 
to be red it can be green orange whatever okay

and now we're just gonna sound it into a paste and 
by the way this paste right here is the great base

for any other stir-fry you might want to do so 
there you just want to get it to something like

this where there are no more big chunks but it's 
not completely liquefied you know a little bit of

roughness texture is good so we're gonna set that 
aside and that's it all we have to do is stir fry

it up so asper any other stir-fry you always want 
to make sure all your mise don't pass is ready to

go because it goes very quickly especially this

heat it in a wok or a large saute pan you don't 
want to get this super super hot because if you

get it so hot you might instantaneously burn your

okay you mean you can even let it heat up together 
when the fish goes in though they want that to be

hot get that going until it's aromatic you can

starts to turn a little Brown cameraman's coughing 
now is as it's gonna happen when you saute chilies

okay in goes the fish cha think that's the cha

is positive really quickly you've only got a small

starts to cook it'll start to crumble quickly and 
go in with your seasoning the remaining fish sauce

some sugar to cut the salt a little bit of water 
when you're stir frying always have a little bit

of water on hand to use that lubrication so so 
good when your pan is getting really hot and

you are starting to burn certain things adding 
a splash of water sort of coolest that cools

everything down instantly and it's also good for 
controlling the amount of sauce okay I'm going

to add my catch I and my peppercorns toss it one 
last time while my fish is still some what's 30

and then let it cook now if you don't want to 
be so delicate with the fish like if you doing

your stir frying raw fish you always need to 
be gentle if you don't want to be gentle you

can also deep fry the fish first dredge it 
in a little bit of flour just a very light

coating deep fry them until it's golden and 
crispy and firm on the outside then you can

really just toss it and not have to worry 
about the fish falling apart but you know

it's a weeknight dinner if it does fall apart no 
big deal now you can tell when it's done when the

fish is starting to flake like if you see you 
see this one fish is starting to flake now so

this should be good don't want to cook fish 
too much especially halibut going with your

Thai basil quickly and then one quick final 
toss and that's it it's done let's plate gosh

I wish you could smell it through the camera 
so good on this halibut is awesome it's nice

and firm and you can put more water to get or

that looks so good and so if you are serving 
want to serve this that's somewhat of a fancy

clean super clean flavor and it's really 
refreshing but it's hot trust me it's hot

but at the same time it's really simple if you

little bit of sugar to cut the salt but you don't

of the seasoning is the reason why you can really

Katai the peppercorns this is something you'll
